thread.title_full: City Council calls on NOPD Chief Michael Harrison to discuss response to Uptown robberies | NOLA.com

author: Greg LaRose, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: City Council calls on NOPD Chief Michael Harrison to discuss response to Uptown robberies
text:
The New Orleans City Council is asking NOPD Superintendent Michael Harrison to discuss his plan of action after the recent armed robbery of three Uptown businesses -- Patois, Atchafalaya and Monkey Hill -- and their customers.
Harrison is set appear before the council's Criminal Justice Committee at 1 p.m. Friday (Oct. 2) in City Hall's auditorium, where he is also expected to discuss broader crime-fighting measures in place across the city.
"The citizens of New Orleans have been clear -- they want to know what the Mayor, the Council and the New Orleans Police Department are doing about the disturbing recent crime reports in New Orleans. With this meeting, we intend to do just that," Councilwoman Susan Guidry, the committee's chairwoman, said in a statement. "The people of New Orleans need to know that their elected officials and police department are taking this threat seriously and that we are working tirelessly to ensure the safety of our citizens."
The NOPD reported five armed robberies on Wednesday, including two teachers who were held up inside Success Preparatory Academy . Police have released a video of the suspect.
The latest string of robberies fraying the nerves of Uptown residents began on the night of Aug. 20 when three gunmen held up workers and diners at Patois on Laurel Street. On Sept 24, two armed suspects made their way into Atchafalaya on Louisiana Avenue and robbed customers and staff.
And Monday night, three suspects went into the Monkey Hill Bar and took wallets from about a dozen patrons as well as taking money from the register and an upstairs office.
The latest NOPD statistics show that, through Sept. 26, there were 676 armed robberies reported this year, an average of 2.51 per day. It's a 4 percent increase over the 650 armed robberies reported through the same date in 2014.
